LG4X-V2

Note

This software was developed by enthusiastic scientists duct-taping code together to make our lives easier. We didn’t account for all the weird ways things could break—so if you’ve found a bug, head over to our GitHub repository and open an issue. We’ll do our best to fix it!

The software and docs are a work in progress. If something’s unclear, open a discussion or issue on our GitHub page —your feedback helps us improve!

About

LG4X-V2 is © 2022-2025 by Julian Andreas Hochhaus and is inspired by its predecessor software LG4X by Hideki Nakajima.

It is built upon the lmfit and the lmfitxps packages, using PyQt5 for its graphical user interface.

Cite this project

If LG4X-V2 has been significant in your research, and you would like to acknowledge it in your academic publication, we suggest citing it via Zenodo:

You can also use our CITATION.cff file to generate a citation.

Publications Using LG4X-V2

    1. Teenakul et al., Treatment of carbon electrodes with Ti3C2Tx MXene coating and thermal method for vanadium redox flow batteries: a comparative study, RSC Adv., 14, 12807-12816 (2024).

    1. Weinert et al., Structural, chemical, and magnetic investigation of a graphene/cobalt/platinum multilayer system on silicon carbide, Nanotechnology, 35, 165702 (2024).

    1. Lamichhane et al., Investigating the synergy of rapidly synthesized iron oxide predecessor and plasma-gaseous species for dye-removal to reuse water in irrigation, Chemosphere, 24, 143040 (2024).

    1. Weinert, Structural, chemical, and magnetic investigation of a graphene/cobalt/platinum multilayer system on silicon carbide: About the formation of magnetic structures in 2D cobalt layers, TU Dortmund, Dissertation (2024).

License

LG4X-V2 is distributed under the MIT license.

Contributing

We welcome contributions, whether they are ideas, documentation improvements, or code enhancements! If you’d like to contribute a new feature or fix existing issues, follow these steps:

  1. Fork the LG4X-V2 repository on GitHub.

  2. Clone your forked repository:

    git clone https://github.com/<your-name>/LG4X-V2.git

  3. Install dependencies:

    pip install -r requirements.txt

  4. Create a new branch for your feature:

    git checkout -b awesome_new_feature

  5. Start coding!

  6. Verify that your changes do not break anything.

  7. Push changes to your forked repository:

    git push origin awesome_new_feature

  8. Open a pull request on the original LG4X-V2 repository: Pull Requests Page.

For additional help, visit our GitHub Discussions page.

Bugs

Oh no, you found a bug in LG4X-V2? Not surprising—after all, we’re not professional programmers, just some enthusiastic scientists duct-taping code together to make our lives easier. We probably didn’t think of all the weird ways things could break (oops).

Head over to our GitHub repository. and open an issue —tell us what went wrong, and we’ll do our best to fix it while pretending we totally knew what we were doing all along!

Code of Conduct

We are committed to fostering a welcoming community for everyone involved in this project. Please review our official Code of Conduct before contributing.
